title: Boualem Sansal, French-Algerian writer detained in Algeria, receives pardon
subhead: Sansal's incarceration since November 2024 had been at the heart of a diplomatic row between France and Algeria. Following mediation by Germany, Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune issued a pardon.
byline: By Simon Roger, Frédéric Bobin and Philippe Ricard

Paris-Berlin night train to be revived by Belgian-Dutch cooperative
subhead: European Sleeper plans to open bookings on December 16 and launch service between the French and German capitals on March 26, 2026, after France's national rail company abandoned the night line.

title: 'There is one issue on which Warren Buffett does not compromise: The greed of corporate executives'
subhead: At 95 years old, the legendary investor is preparing to step down as chair of Berkshire Hathaway. In a letter to shareholders, he delivers a lesson in humility, writes Isabelle Chaperon, columnist for Le Monde's economy desk.

title: 'Everybody Scream' by Florence and the Machine: An album between life and death
subhead: With a sixth album haunted by witchcraft, the British rock band continues its exploration of opposites.

title: 10 years after Paris attacks: 'I wanted my testimony to serve the collective memory,' says Bataclan survivor
subhead: Photographer Mathieu G., 45, was not physically injured during the attack on the concert hall but has suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder. For nearly 10 years, he has participated in the November 13 Program, an interdisciplinary research project.
byline: By Nathalie Brafman and Pascale Santi

The new malaise of civilization: When words, truth and reality fall apart
subhead: The proliferation of wars, increase in mental health disorders, devaluation of speech, and loss of connection to reality are troubling signs of the tipping point our societies are facing. Nearly a century ago, Freud identified a malaise that resonates with what we are going through today.

title: Among France's centrists, Macron's succession is still anyone's game
subhead: A year and a half ahead of the 2027 presidential election, no 'natural' candidate has managed to dominate the fractured former majority coalition. Edouard Philippe, the only declared candidate, has distanced himself from Emmanuel Macron, while Gabriel Attal has held back.

title: She was hanging from the Bataclan's window. He caught her hand.
subhead: Sébastien and Charlotte should never have met. Yet their lives have been inextricably linked since a tragic night in November 2015, when the young man saved the pregnant woman clinging to a window ledge as they both tried to escape the terrorists.
